oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Friendship CME: abandoned building
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: West, Carroll Van, photographer
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Color photograph of abandoned building on the north side of Manley's Chapel RD, located across from Friendship CME Church. This abandoned building may be the old block school used by Friendship CME Church before the current church building was constructed.

Established around 1879 as Moore Chapel Colored Methodist Episcopal Church, later renamed Friendship Christian Methodist Episcopal, the church is believed to be one of Benton County’s oldest churches. A small cemetery affiliated with the church, known as Moore Chapel-Flatwoods Cemetery, was established ca. 1881. The original church building stood on the same site occupied by the current building. After the original building started to deteriorate, the congregation used a school building owned by Moore’s Chapel Methodist Church. Friendship CME later acquired one acre of land to construct a new church building and cemetery on the original site, completing the building in 1989. Reverends Geneva Cherry and J.E. Robinson served as pastors at the time the property was investigated.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: African American Churches -- Tennessee; School buildings
derelict buildings
